stream_context.summary: Kaze focuses on Course 15, “Astro Arcade,” the last main stage of Return to Yoshi’s Island, coding new pinball-style objects while reviewing tester feedback that forces a redesign of earlier Course 3 navigation.

development_findings.summary: Course 15, titled “Astro Arcade,” is confirmed as the final main course; three side levels and the overworlds remain afterward.

The level’s core gimmick is a space-themed pinball arena featuring five interactable parts: rotating flipper, spherical bumper, triangular bumper, metal stand-on panels (likely to be redesigned), and a trampoline pad that launches Mario upward.
development_findings.quote: We’re actually working on the flipper pieces right now in the asteroid arcade. We need a flipper piece that rotates and flings the ball back up… and a trampoline piece that just shoots you up.

development_findings.summary: Metal panels currently look ‘ugly’; Kaze intends to scrap or re-texture them and is experimenting with arcade-carpet and tiled textures for general platforms.
Flipper logic now biases the launch vector upward, grants air-control, removes fall damage on landing, and scales visually when hit, making the mechanic both readable and forgiving.
development_findings.quote: Now you always get shot mostly up… I also turned off fall damage so you can realistically not die.

development_findings.summary: Kaze will add a glowing ring inspired by Mario Kart 8 and dynamic lighting to strengthen the arcade aesthetic.
development_findings.quote: That ring… is so cool. I need that in the level. I don’t know what it’s going to do, but I need it.

development_findings.summary: Testing revealed Course 3 navigation fails: players locate the retro 8-bit pipe too early and miss the intended main path. Planned fixes: move pipe to a visible but inaccessible spot, simplify jumps, use stronger visual guidance (signs, coin arrows).
development_findings.quote: The overall conclusion is the player really needs to be guided to Star 1 a lot more.

development_findings.summary: A demo release is planned with only Course 1 plus a Delfino-Plaza overworld; updated controls and camera received unanimous positive feedback from testers.
development_findings.quote: Everyone that played the demo thought that the new controls and camera were great.

development_findings.summary: Memory strategy: game requires Expansion Pak; Kaze splits framebuffers to create two free memory chunks and has exploited a ‘hidden ninth bit’ to access an extra 1 MB, though this hack breaks on most emulators.
development_findings.quote: We found a way to use an extra one megabyte in the N64, and it doesn’t work on emulators.

development_findings.summary: Debate on whether to add global ‘void protection’ (bubble rescue) in Course 15; currently only certain stages use it via birds or oil.
Star-pad visual feedback undecided; idea is dim star that brightens on contact, with Biobak tasked to refine the animation.
Kaze rejects suggestions that resemble Sonic, stressing a Mario Galaxy tone; for example, he vetoed transparent ‘ball tubes.’
development_findings.quote: I don’t want people to say you copied Sonic… We want this to be more Mario Galaxy than Sonic.

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s design philosophy mirrors Mario 64: make the first star path obvious so players map out the level before exploring freely.
context_findings.quote: That’s what we want to do. We want to make it very obvious where to go at first.

context_findings.summary: He is highly reactive to tester feedback, calling one recording ‘depressing’ yet using it to reshape Course 3.
Expresses continual worry about Nintendo DMCA strikes; intends the trailer to be clearly fair-use and includes an in-game screen warning buyers they were scammed if they paid money.
Mentions personal workload (‘catch up on 100 hours of work’) and banters with chat on colors, ethics, and greetings, showing typical live-stream informality.

biobak.summary: Delivered the demo’s Delfino-Plaza overworld model; Kaze showcased it on-stream.
Will design the star-pad blink animation and proposed ‘ball tube’ platforms (idea ultimately declined).

badub.summary: Composer is willing to share isolated sound-effect files; current build already uses his new camera/controls praise.
badub.quote: Anyone receive media files for these unused sound effects? … You’d have to ask Badub, but I’m sure he’s up for it.

zeina.summary: Gave visual feedback (called the metal panel ‘ugly’), resubscribed on stream, and briefly appeared off-camera bringing Kaze hot chocolate.

key_stories.title: Course 3 Navigation Crisis
key_stories.summary: A tester spent 25 minutes, earned only one star, and quit, exposing serious way-finding flaws. Kaze catalogued issues and is redesigning entry flow.
key_stories.challenge: Players overlook the main path and reach the difficult 8-bit pipe immediately.
key_stories.process: Relocate pipe out of reach, add clearer visual cues (signs, coin arrows), lower jump difficulty.
key_stories.key_quote: The player really needs to be guided to Star 1 a lot more.

key_stories.title: Building the Flipper System
key_stories.summary: During the stream Kaze models, programs, and debugs the pinball flipper, refining bounce angles, scaling animation, and safety features.
key_stories.challenge: Create a readable, fun flipper that doesn’t kill the player.
key_stories.process: Test normals, add upward bias, grant air control, disable fall damage, tweak scale speed.
key_stories.outcome: Functional prototype now anchors Course 15 design.
key_stories.key_quote: This feels very controllable to me, but I’m also the guy that programmed it so that doesn’t mean too much.

key_stories.title: Squeezing Extra Memory from the N64
key_stories.summary: Kaze discovered a way to unlock an undocumented megabyte of RAM via a ‘hidden ninth bit’.
key_stories.challenge: Need more memory without sacrificing speed.
key_stories.process: Segment framebuffers, exploit hidden bit; prepare explanatory video.
key_stories.outcome: Technique works on real hardware but breaks emulators; video will publicize it.
key_stories.key_quote: We found a way to use an extra one megabyte in the N64, and it doesn’t work on emulators.

open_questions.context: Kaze listed problems and high-level fixes but no concrete new layout yet.
questions: What exact changes will you make to ensure players see the correct path first?
Will the Mario World castle and gap be rebuilt or simply toned down?

open_questions.context: Current metal pieces are deemed ugly; carpet/tile or new geometry discussed but undecided.
questions: What final visual language will replace the metal panels?
Who will author and implement the new assets?

open_questions.context: Some stages rescue the player after falls; Course 15 status undecided.
questions: Will a global bubble-rescue be added to Course 15 or the whole game?
How will you convey to players when void protection is or isn’t active?

open_questions.context: Biobak to refine blinking/glow but no final design chosen.
questions: What visual behavior best communicates ‘bounce-ready’ without clutter?
Do technical limits (additive glow, clamping) constrain the effect?

open_questions.context: Planned Course 1 demo with new overworld and camera, sometime before Christmas.
questions: What is the concrete release schedule?
What feedback do you hope to gather from the limited demo?
